text: INT. HOUSE - DAY
We MOVE THROUGH an ordinary house.  Ordinary living room.
Ordinary kitchen.  Ordinary bathroom.
Silence.  But this silence is oppressive, not peaceful.
We move into the
INT. BEDROOM - DAY
preview: which is unoccupied.  Over to the perfectly-made bed.

text: ORDINARY BEDROOM
which is unoccupied.  Over to the perfectly-made bed.
A SOUND.  Barely perceivable.  Possibly a WHIMPER.
We move down
UNDER THE BED
where a TERRIFIED YOUNG WOMAN shakes uncontrollably with
fear.  One hand is clamped over her mouth to muffle the
sound; the other grasps her opposite wrist to hold it in
place.  Tears stream down her face.
The sound of FOOTSTEPS.  If it was possible for the Terrified
Young Woman's eyes to grow wider, they do.
The footsteps grow louder.  They come into the room.  Over to
the bed.  A pair of nondescript shoes.
The Terrified Young Woman snaps her eyes shut.  Prays.  She
can't bear to look.
Then, without looking underneath, the owner of the shoes
moves away from the bed.  Toward the door of the room.  The
footsteps grow quieter.
The Terrified Young Woman opens her eyes.
Finally, she musters the courage to crane her neck out from
under the bed.  She looks from side to side.  The room is
empty.
She looks up quickly, as if expecting her pursuer to be
standing on the bed, ready to attack.  But again, nothing.
Quietly, she slides out from under the bed and gets to her
feet.  She gives a cursory look around the room.
Slowly, she makes her way to the door.  She moves her head
past the frame.  Looks one way down the hall, then they other
way.  Deserted.
INT. HALLWAY - DAY
preview: back, takes one step into the hallway.

text: The Terrified Young Woman, whose courage is slowly coming
back, takes one step into the hallway.
The tension is unbearable.  We just know, despite what we've
seen, that SOMETHING is waiting in the hallway for her.
But nothing is.  It's empty.  She breathes a sigh of relief.
As do we.
She walks softly over to the steps.  Then takes them one at a
time, praying they won't creak and give her away.
She can hardly believe she makes it to the bottom unmolested.
The hint of a smile even tugs at her lips.
But it's short-lived...
A sound from one of the bedrooms.  Then a shadow across the
top of the stairs.
INT. FRONT DOOR - DAY
preview: makes a mad dash for the front door.

text: Silence is no longer necessary.  The Terrified Young Woman
makes a mad dash for the front door.
She grabs the doorknob.  Yanks on it.  Not thinking straight.
The footsteps pound down the steps behind her.
She manages to unlock the dead bolt.  Pulls open the door.
The chain holds, taunting her.  She slams the door shut.
Throws the chain.  Yanks it open.
EXT. HOUSE - DAY
preview: threshold.  Freedom is only inches away.

text: The door flies opens.  The Terrified Young Woman is on the
threshold.  Freedom is only inches away.
But before she can take a single step, she is snatched back
inside.  The slamming of the door cuts short her scream.
And once again, the neighborhood is peaceful.  Like nothing
ever happened...
Title Card: NEXT DOOR
EXT. PARK EAST TOWNHOME PARK - DAY
preview: Hundreds of nearly identical, two-story townhouses line the

text: The morning sun shines over PARK EAST AT THE RENAISSANCE.
Hundreds of nearly identical, two-story townhouses line the
streets that snake around this meticulously maintained
development.
The conformity is at once reassuring and creepy.
A U-Haul rumbles down the street.  A WOMAN looks out of the
vehicle's passenger side window as the townhouses pass by in
a blur.
Behind some of the units is a retention pond, landscaped to
appear as a naturally occurring body of water.  It's ringed
by a paved path, used by joggers and young families pushing
strollers.
The U-Haul pulls into the shared driveway of one of the end
units.  Unlike the majority of the townhouses, end units only
share a single common wall with the adjacent townhouse, in
addition to the driveway.
The woman, CHLOE ANDERSON (early-30's), steps out of the U-
Haul.  She stretches as the cool breeze blows her light brown
hair away from her face.
She stands on the driveway, studying the townhouse in front
of her with a hint of trepidation.
Her husband, MICHAEL ANDERSON -- same age and equally
attractive -- walks up behind her.  She doesn't acknowledge
him.
CHLOE
(half to herself)
What is this place?
Michael leans over and kisses her on the cheek.
MICHAEL
Home.
He returns to the truck, leaving Chloe to her thoughts as the
sun dips behind the rooftops.
INT. ANDERSON TOWNHOUSE - DAY
preview: some open -- are strewn across the room.  On the outside of

text: The unpacking has begun.  Cardboard boxes -- some closed,
some open -- are strewn across the room.  On the outside of
the boxes, in permanent marker, the contents within have been
diligently described.
The floor is littered with bubble wrap, packing tape,
crumpled paper, and every other bit of moving day detritus.
Michael calls down from somewhere in the second story of the
house.
MICHAEL (O.S.)
Chlo?
Chloe doesn't answer.  She pulls open the top flap of a box
marked: PICTURES/VASES/CHINA.
She reaches inside and takes out a framed photo.
INSERT - PHOTO
The happy couple on a tropical beach, cocktails in hand.
The smiling, carefree woman in the photo looks much different
than the one whose face is reflected in the glass of the
frame.
BACK TO SCENE
Michael calls out again, louder this time.
MICHAEL (O.S.)
Chloe?  You down there?
Chloe frowns and puts the frame back into the box.
CHLOE
I'm here.
MICHAEL (O.S.)

children.text: You know where my shoe tree is?
She raises her voice to be heard.

text: You know where my shoe tree is?
She raises her voice to be heard.
CHLOE

children.text: It's with the movers.  We packed it

text: It's with the movers.  We packed it
with the bedroom furniture.
Silence, as Michael considers his predicament.
MICHAEL (O.S.)
When are they coming again?
Chloe sighs to herself.  It's a question he's asked her a
dozen times already.
CHLOE
Tomorrow.  Between nine and eleven.
The sound of FOOTSTEPS.
Michael comes down the stairs.  He holds up his iPhone,
sheepishly.
MICHAEL
I got a text.
Chloe nods at him.  She was expecting this.
MICHAEL

children.text: I really need to be downtown.
He points to the mess around them.

text: I really need to be downtown.
He points to the mess around them.
MICHAEL

children.text: It's not just all this.  I mean, we

text: It's not just all this.  I mean, we
don't even have Internet.
CHLOE
Go.  It's okay.
Michael doesn't need to be told twice.  He grabs his
briefcase and is almost out the door before he calls back to
her.
MICHAEL

children.text: I'll be home for dinner.  I

text: I'll be home for dinner.  I
promise.
As the door slams shut, Chloe lies down on the floor, both
exhausted and overwhelmed at the task ahead of her.
INT. ANDERSON TOWNHOUSE - NIGHT
preview: her lap.  She shovels peanut butter noodles into her mouth

text: Chloe sits on the floor with a Chinese take out container in
her lap.  She shovels peanut butter noodles into her mouth
with chopsticks.
The house is dark.  The only light comes from the enormous
flat screen TV which sits on the floor in front of her.
The picture on the screen is ridiculously fuzzy, far from the
pristine image to which we've all grown accustomed.  It's
obvious the cable hasn't been installed yet.  Chloe is
watching whatever broadcast station the TV's internal antenna
can pull from the airwaves.
Next to her is an empty wine glass and a plate of Szechuan
beef.  She looks at the glass then glances at her watch.  She
pours herself another.
EXT. ANDERSON TOWNHOUSE - DAY
preview: her back door.  With one hand holding the body of the camera,

text: Chloe kneels down on the small concrete porch right outside
her back door.  With one hand holding the body of the camera,
and the other resting underneath the massive lens, she snaps
away.
She makes small adjustments causally, without even looking at
the camera.  As if it's second nature.
Once the telephoto lens has exhausted its purpose, Chloe gets
to her feet and walks across the ten yards of grass that lead
to the bank of the pond.
She snaps a few more shots and smiles, satisfied, then turns
around and walks back up the slope of her backyard.
Just before reaching her property, she glances at the back
door of her next door neighbor's townhouse.
The curtains are drawn but open just enough to reveal a hint
of what's inside.  And this hint is just enough to pique
Chloe's curiosity.
She raises her camera to shoulder level and looks at the
small LCD monitor.
INSERT - LCD MONITOR
The curtains rustle.  Motion.  Shapes and shades moving
within.
BACK TO SCENE
Chloe moves the camera away from her face.  She blinks,
giving her eyes a rest.  Then she looks at the LCD monitor
again.
INSERT - LCD MONITOR
An image comes into focus.  It can only be...an eyeball.
Looking back at Chloe from behind the curtains.
BACK TO SCENE
Chloe jumps back, as if whatever is behind the door was close
enough to touch her, instead of a good twenty yards away.
Finished spying for the day, she hurries back to her own
house.
She turns away without saying a word and retreats into the
bathroom, shutting the door behind her.  Michael groans and
sticks his head under the pillow.  It's going to be one of
those nights.
INT. ANDERSON TOWNHOUSE - DAY
The house is almost in order.  All the garbage and packing
supplies have been thrown away.
Chloe, dressed in her ratty old jeans with her hair tied up
in the bandana, cleans the house.
-- Spraying Windex on the windows and wiping the glass with
rags
-- Polishing the faucets in the kitchen
-- Mopping the floors
-- Hanging her remaining framed photos on the walls
Basically, making their house a home.
Chloe stands up and stretches.  GROANS.  Reaches for the
ceiling.  The muscles in her back and legs screaming for
relief.
EXT. ANDERSON TOWNHOUSE - DAY
preview: about fifty yards from the mouth of her driveway.

text: Chloe walks out the front door, over to the communal mailbox
about fifty yards from the mouth of her driveway.
As she approaches the mailbox she reaches into her pocket.
Her face drops, then turns white.
CHLOE
(to herself)
Oh, no.  No, no, no...
She jabs her hands into her pockets -- front, back, sides,
coming away with nothing.
Frantic, she runs back to her
FRONT DOOR
taking the most direct route across the front lawn.  She
throws open the screen door and grabs the doorknob, knowing
full well what to expect.
LOCKED.
